Stability of Regime-Switching Diffusion Systems with Discrete States Belonging to a Countable Set‚Ä†‚Ä†thanks: This research was supported in part by the National Science Foundation under grant DMS-1207667.

Dang Hai Nguyen Department of Mathematics, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, dangnh.maths@gmail.com. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ George Yin Department of Mathematics, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, gyin@math.wayne.edu.
Abstract

This work focuses on stability of regime-switching diffusions consisting of continuous and discrete components, in which the discrete component switches in a countably infinite set and its switching rates at current time depend on the continuous component. In contrast to the existing approach, this work provides more practically viable approach with more feasible conditions for stability. A classical approach for asymptotic stability using Lyapunov function techniques shows the Lyapunov function evaluated at the solution process goes to 0 as time t‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë°t\to\infty. A distinctive feature of this paper is to obtain estimates of path-wise rates of convergence, which pinpoints how fast the aforementioned convergence to 0 taking place. Finally, some examples are given to illustrate our findings.


Keywords. Switching diffusion, past-dependent switching, existence and uniqueness of solution, Feller property.


Subject Classification. 34D20, 60H10, 93D05, 93D20.

1 Introduction

In the new era, because of the pressing needs in networked systems (including physical, biological, ecological, and social dynamic systems), large-scale optimization, and wired and wireless communications, many new sophisticated control systems have come into being. Hybrid systems in which discrete and continuous states coexist and interact, are such a representative. In particular, taking random disturbances into consideration, the so-called regime-switching diffusion systems have drawn resurgent and increasing attentions. A regime-switching diffusion is a two-component process (X‚Äã(t),Œ±‚Äã(t))ùëãùë°ùõºùë°(X(t),\alpha(t)), a continuous component and a discrete component taking values in a set consisting of isolated points. When the discrete component takes a value iùëñi (i.e., Œ±‚Äã(t)=iùõºùë°ùëñ\alpha(t)=i), the continuous component X‚Äã(t)ùëãùë°X(t) evolves according to the diffusion process whose drift and diffusion coefficients depend on iùëñi. Asymptotic properties of such systems such as stability have been studied intensively, because of numerous applications. For example, many issues such as permanence, extinction, and persistence etc. of species in population dynamics and ecology are all linked to the stability issues.

Because many systems are in operation for a long period of time, an important problem of great interest is the stability of such systems. Many results on different types of stability have been given for switching diffusions when the state space of Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t) is finite (e.g., [9, 12, 19, 22, 23]). Assuming that Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t) takes values in a countable state space, stability of the processes is more difficult to analyze. To the best of our knowledge, very few papers have considered stability of switching diffusion with countable switching states. In [15], some conditions for stability of those systems have been given by approximating the generator of continuous state dependent switching process by that of a Markov chain with finite state space.

To find sufficient conditions for stability, it is desirable to find some common threads that are shared by many specific systems. Our motivation is based on the following thoughts. First, although the dynamics of X‚Äã(t)ùëãùë°X(t) depend on the residence of the state of Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t), the structures of equations for different states of Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t) are not drastically different but rather similar in certain sense. This observation suggests finding a Lyapunov function that has similar form in different states of Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t). For instance, suppose there is a Lyapunov function V‚Äã(x)ùëâùë•V(x) such that in each discrete state iùëñi, we have ‚Ñíi‚ÄãV‚Äã(x)‚â§ci‚ÄãV‚Äã(x)subscript‚Ñíùëñùëâùë•subscriptùëêùëñùëâùë•\mathcal{L}_{i}V(x)\leq c_{i}V(x), where ‚Ñíisubscript‚Ñíùëñ\mathcal{L}_{i} is the generator of the diffusion in regime iùëñi (more conditions and explanations for this inequality and related issues will be given in the next sections). In this case, there is a common Lyapunov function shared by all the discrete states (or the Lyapunov function is independent of the discrete states). It is well known that the sign of cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i} determines stability of the diffusion in each state iùëñi. For the regime-switching diffusion, one can expect that the stability of the system depends not only on {ci}subscriptùëêùëñ\{c_{i}\} but also on the generator Q‚Äã(x)ùëÑùë•Q(x) of the switching part. A natural question is: under what relation between {ci}subscriptùëêùëñ\{c_{i}\} and Q‚Äã(x)ùëÑùë•Q(x), the regime-switching diffusion is stable? When the number of regimes is finite, this question has been answered relatively completely (see [9, 15]). However, it is not straightforward to answer this question for the case of the discrete states belonging to a countable state space. We aim to take the challenges here. Moreover, this paper also considers a generalization when the condition ‚Ñíi‚ÄãV‚Äã(x)‚â§ci‚ÄãV‚Äã(x)subscript‚Ñíùëñùëâùë•subscriptùëêùëñùëâùë•\mathcal{L}_{i}V(x)\leq c_{i}V(x) is replaced with a condition of the type ‚Ñíi‚ÄãV‚Äã(x)‚â§ci‚Äãg‚Äã(V‚Äã(x))subscript‚Ñíùëñùëâùë•subscriptùëêùëñùëîùëâùë•\mathcal{L}_{i}V(x)\leq c_{i}g(V(x)).

To date, muck work has been devoted to the asymptotic stability of diffusions and switching diffusions. A commonly used technique is based on Lyapunov stability argument. For example, treating asymptotic stability, much effort has been devoted to obtaining sufficient conditions under which the Lyapunov function evaluated at the solutions of the processes go to 0 as t‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë°t\to\infty. However, the question on how fast the Lyapunov function goes to 0 is unknown to date to the best of our knowledge. The current paper settles this issue; it may be one of the first to provide a convergence rate of the underlying process. As another novel contribution, we estimate the convergence rate of the solution to the equilibrium point by use of properties of the function g‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëî‚ãÖg(\cdot).

Treating switching diffusions as Markov processes, one may obtain sufficient conditions for stability by using a Lyapunov function satisfying certain properties. However, the conditions are often not directly related to the given system coefficients (such as the drifts and diffusion matrices). To obtain conditions that are based on coefficients of the systems, we look at the issue of linearized (about the point of equilibrium) of the systems. The idea is originated from the topological equivalence of the linearized systems and original nonlinear systems due to the well-known Hartman-Grobman theorem in differential equations. Here in addition to linearizing the systems about the equilibrium point, we also replace Q‚Äã(x)ùëÑùë•Q(x) by Q‚Äã(0)ùëÑ0Q(0).

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we formulate the equation for a regime-switching diffusion and pose appropriate conditions for the existence and uniqueness of solutions. We then provide the definitions of certain types of stability as well as give general conditions for the stability of switching. In Section 3, novel and practical conditions for stability and instability of regime-switching diffusions are given. Applications of these conditions to linearizable systems are given in Section 4 and examples are provided in Section 5 to illustrate our findings. Section 6 is devoted to several remarks. Finally, we provide the proofs of a number of technical results in an appendix.

Definition 2.3.

  • ‚Ä¢

    strongly ergodic, if

    limt‚Üí‚àûsupi‚àà‚Ñ§+{‚àëj‚àà‚Ñ§+|p^i‚Äãj‚Äã(t)‚àíŒΩj|}=0.subscript‚Üíùë°subscriptsupremumùëñsubscript‚Ñ§subscriptùëósubscript‚Ñ§subscript^ùëùùëñùëóùë°subscriptùúàùëó0\lim_{t\to\infty}\sup_{i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}\left\{\sum_{j\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}|\widehat{p}_{ij}(t)-\nu_{j}|\right\}=0.

    strongly exponentially ergodic, if there exist C>0ùê∂0C>0 and Œª>0ùúÜ0\lambda>0 such that

We refer to [3] for some properties and sufficient conditions for the aforementioned ergodicity.

3 Certain Practical Conditions for Stability and Instability

By Theorem 2.2, it follows from (3.7) that the trivial solution is asymptotically stable. ‚àé

The hypothesis of this theorem seems to be restrictive. It requires the strongly exponential ergodicity of Q‚Äã(0)ùëÑ0Q(0) and the uniform convergence to 0 of the sum ‚àëj‚â†i|qi‚Äãj‚Äã(x)‚àíqi‚Äãj‚Äã(0)|subscriptùëóùëñsubscriptùëûùëñùëóùë•subscriptùëûùëñùëó0\sum_{j\neq i}|q_{ij}(x)-q_{ij}(0)|. To treat cases in which Q‚Äã(0)ùëÑ0Q(0) is strongly ergodic (not exponentially ergodic) or even only ergodic, as well as to relax the condition (3.1), we need a more complicated method. Our method, which is inspired by the idea in [6], utilizes the ergodicity of Q‚Äã(0)ùëÑ0Q(0) and the analysis of the Laplace transform. Similar techniques of using the Laplace transform can also be seen in the large deviations theory and related applications [5, 24]. We also take a step further by estimating the pathwise rate of convergence of solutions.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a family of increasing and continuously differentiable functions g:‚Ñù+‚Ü¶‚Ñù+:ùëîmaps-tosubscript‚Ñùsubscript‚Ñùg:\mathbb{R}_{+}\mapsto\mathbb{R}_{+} such that g‚Äã(y)=0ùëîùë¶0g(y)=0 iff y=0ùë¶0y=0. Remark 3.1.

Before proceeding to the proof of the theorem, let us make a brief comment. In addition to providing sufficient conditions for asymptotic stability, a significant new element here is the rate of convergence given in (3.12). Although there are numerous treatment of stochastic stability by a host of authors for diffusions and switching diffusions. The rate result in Theorem 3.2 appears to the first one of its kind.

Proof.

The proof is divided into two steps. We first show the trivial solution is stable in probability and then we prove asymptotic stability and estimate the path-wise convergence rate.

Theorem 3.6.

    there is a bounded sequence of real numbers {ci:i‚àà‚Ñ§+}conditional-setsubscriptùëêùëñùëñsubscript‚Ñ§\{c_{i}:i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}\} such that

4 Linearized Systems

Suppose that (3.44) is satisfied and that Œ±^‚Äã(t)^ùõºùë°\widehat{\alpha}(t) is a strongly ergodic Markov chain.

(4.3)

(Note that the existence of such pùëùp and ‚ÑèPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar satisfying (4.3) uniformly for i‚àà‚Ñ§+ùëñsubscript‚Ñ§i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+} is due to (4.3) and the boundedness of Œõ1,isubscriptŒõ1ùëñ\Lambda_{1,i} and Œõ2,i,ksubscriptŒõ2ùëñùëò\Lambda_{2,i,k}.)

‚Ñôx,i‚Äã{limt‚Üí‚àûeŒª‚Äãt‚Äã|X‚Äã(t)|‚â§1}‚â•1‚àíŒµ‚Äã¬†for¬†‚Äã(x,i)‚ààBŒ¥√ó‚Ñ§+.subscript‚Ñôùë•ùëñsubscript‚Üíùë°superscriptùëíùúÜùë°ùëãùë°11ùúÄ¬†for¬†ùë•ùëñsubscriptùêµùõøsubscript‚Ñ§\mathbb{P}_{x,i}\left\{\lim_{t\to\infty}e^{\lambda t}|X(t)|\leq 1\right\}\geq 1-\varepsilon\,\text{ for }(x,i)\in B_{\delta}\times{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}.

Similarly, if ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñ§+ŒΩi‚Äã(Œª1,i+12‚Äã‚àëk=1nŒª2,i,k)>0,subscriptùëñsubscript‚Ñ§subscriptùúàùëñsubscriptùúÜ1ùëñ12superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëõsubscriptùúÜ2ùëñùëò0\sum_{i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}\nu_{i}\left(\lambda_{1,i}+\dfrac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\lambda_{2,i,k}\right)>0, and if Œª1,isubscriptùúÜ1ùëñ\lambda_{1,i} and Œª2,i,ksubscriptùúÜ2ùëñùëò\lambda_{2,i,k} are bounded in i‚àà‚Ñ§+,k=1,‚Ä¶,nformulae-sequenceùëñsubscript‚Ñ§ùëò1‚Ä¶ùëõi\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+},k=1,\dots,n, we have that the trivial solution is unstable. To sum up, we have the following result.

Proposition 4.1.

Let Assumption 4.1 is satisfied. We claim that,

  • ‚Ä¢

    if Œõ1,isubscriptŒõ1ùëñ\Lambda_{1,i} and Œõ2,i,ksubscriptŒõ2ùëñùëò\Lambda_{2,i,k} are bounded in i‚àà‚Ñ§+ùëñsubscript‚Ñ§i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+} and

    ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñ§+ŒΩi‚Äã(Œõ1,i+12‚Äã‚àëk=1nŒõ2,i,k)<0,subscriptùëñsubscript‚Ñ§subscriptùúàùëñsubscriptŒõ1ùëñ12superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëõsubscriptŒõ2ùëñùëò0\sum_{i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}\nu_{i}\left(\Lambda_{1,i}+\dfrac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\Lambda_{2,i,k}\right)<0,

    then the trivial solution is asymptotically stable in probability;

  • ‚Ä¢

    if Œª1,isubscriptùúÜ1ùëñ\lambda_{1,i} and Œª2,i,ksubscriptùúÜ2ùëñùëò\lambda_{2,i,k} are bounded in i‚àà‚Ñ§+,k=1,‚Ä¶,nformulae-sequenceùëñsubscript‚Ñ§ùëò1‚Ä¶ùëõi\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+},k=1,\dots,n, and

    ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñ§+ŒΩi‚Äã(Œª1,i+12‚Äã‚àëk=1nŒª2,i,k)>0,subscriptùëñsubscript‚Ñ§subscriptùúàùëñsubscriptùúÜ1ùëñ12superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëõsubscriptùúÜ2ùëñùëò0\sum_{i\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}\nu_{i}\left(\lambda_{1,i}+\dfrac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^{n}\lambda_{2,i,k}\right)>0,

    then the trivial solution is unstable in probability.

5 Examples

This section provides several examples.

Example 5.1.

Consider a real-valued switching diffusion

d‚ÄãX‚Äã(t)=b‚Äã(Œ±‚Äã(t))‚ÄãX‚Äã(t)‚Äã[|X‚Äã(t)|Œ≥‚à®1]‚Äãd‚Äãt+œÉ‚Äã(Œ±‚Äã(t))‚Äãsin2‚Å°X‚Äã(t)‚Äãd‚ÄãW‚Äã(t),‚Äâ‚Äâ0<Œ≥<1,formulae-sequenceùëëùëãùë°ùëèùõºùë°ùëãùë°delimited-[]superscriptùëãùë°ùõæ1ùëëùë°ùúéùõºùë°superscript2ùëãùë°ùëëùëäùë°‚Äâ‚Äâ0ùõæ1dX(t)=b(\alpha(t))X(t)[|X(t)|^{\gamma}\vee 1]dt+\sigma(\alpha(t))\sin^{2}X(t)dW(t),\,\,0<\gamma<1, (5.1)

qi‚Äãj‚Äã(x)={‚àípÀá1‚Äã(x)¬†if¬†‚Äãi=j=1pÀá1‚Äã(x)¬†if¬†‚Äãi=1,j=2‚àíp^i‚Äã(x)‚àípÀái‚Äã(x)¬†if¬†‚Äãi=j‚â•2p^i‚Äã(x)¬†if¬†‚Äãi‚â•2,j=i‚àí1pÀái‚Äã(x)¬†if¬†‚Äãi‚â•2,j=i+1.subscriptùëûùëñùëóùë•casessubscriptÀáùëù1ùë•¬†if¬†ùëñùëó1subscriptÀáùëù1ùë•formulae-sequence¬†if¬†ùëñ1ùëó2subscript^ùëùùëñùë•subscriptÀáùëùùëñùë•¬†if¬†ùëñùëó2subscript^ùëùùëñùë•formulae-sequence¬†if¬†ùëñ2ùëóùëñ1subscriptÀáùëùùëñùë•formulae-sequence¬†if¬†ùëñ2ùëóùëñ1q_{ij}(x)=\begin{cases}-\check{p}_{1}(x)&\,\text{ if }i=j=1\\ \check{p}_{1}(x)&\,\text{ if }i=1,j=2\\ -\widehat{p}_{i}(x)-\check{p}_{i}(x)&\,\text{ if }i=j\geq 2\\ \widehat{p}_{i}(x)&\,\text{ if }i\geq 2,j=i-1\\ \check{p}_{i}(x)&\,\text{ if }i\geq 2,j=i+1.\end{cases}

Example 5.2.

Under this condition, the switching differential system is unstable.

6 Further Remarks

Using a new method, we provide sufficient conditions for stability and instability in probability of a class of regime-switching diffusion systems with switching states belonging to a countable set. The conditions are based on the relation of a ‚Äúswitching-independent‚Äù Lyapunov function and the generator of the switching part.

Although the systems under consideration are memoryless, the main results of this paper hold if we assume that the switching intensities qi‚Äãjsubscriptùëûùëñùëóq_{ij} depend on the history of {X‚Äã(t)}ùëãùë°\{X(t)\} rather than the current state of X‚Äã(t)ùëãùë°X(t), (see [13, 14] for fundamental properties of this process). The problem can be formulated as follows. Let rùëür be a fixed positive number. Denote by ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} the set of ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ\mathbb{R}^{n}-valued continuous functions defined on [‚àír,0]ùëü0[-r,0]. For œï‚ààùíûitalic-œïùíû\phi\in\mathcal{C}, we use the norm ‚à•œï‚à•=sup{|œï(t)|:t‚àà[‚àír,0]}\|\phi\|=\sup\{|\phi(t)|:t\in[-r,0]\}. For t‚â•0ùë°0t\geq 0, we denote by ytsubscriptùë¶ùë°y_{t} the so-called segment function (or memory segment function) yt={y‚Äã(t+s):‚àír‚â§s‚â§0}subscriptùë¶ùë°conditional-setùë¶ùë°ùë†ùëüùë†0y_{t}=\{y(t+s):-r\leq s\leq 0\}. We assume that the jump intensity of Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t) depends on the trajectory of X‚Äã(t)ùëãùë°X(t) in the interval [t‚àír,t]ùë°ùëüùë°[t-r,t]. That is, there are functions qi‚Äãj‚Äã(‚ãÖ):ùíû‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëûùëñùëó‚ãÖ‚Üíùíû‚Ñùq_{ij}(\cdot):\mathcal{C}\to\mathbb{R} for i,j‚àà‚Ñ§+ùëñùëósubscript‚Ñ§i,j\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+} satisfying that qi‚Äã(œï):=‚àëj=1,j‚â†i‚àûqi‚Äãj‚Äã(œï)assignsubscriptùëûùëñitalic-œïsuperscriptsubscriptformulae-sequenceùëó1ùëóùëñsubscriptùëûùëñùëóitalic-œïq_{i}(\phi):=\sum_{j=1,j\neq i}^{\infty}q_{ij}(\phi) is uniformly bounded in (œï,i)‚ààùíû√ó‚Ñ§+italic-œïùëñùíûsubscript‚Ñ§(\phi,i)\in\mathcal{C}\times{\mathbb{Z}}_{+} and that qi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëûùëñ‚ãÖq_{i}(\cdot) and qi‚Äãj‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëûùëñùëó‚ãÖq_{ij}(\cdot) are continuous such that

‚Ñô‚Äã{Œ±‚Äã(t+Œî)=j|Œ±‚Äã(t)=i,Xs,Œ±‚Äã(s),s‚â§t}=qi‚Äãj‚Äã(Xt)‚ÄãŒî+o‚Äã(Œî)‚Äã¬†if¬†‚Äãi‚â†j‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Ñô‚Äã{Œ±‚Äã(t+Œî)=i|Œ±‚Äã(t)=i,Xs,Œ±‚Äã(s),s‚â§t}=1‚àíqi‚Äã(Xt)‚ÄãŒî+o‚Äã(Œî).missing-subexpression‚Ñôconditional-setùõºùë°Œîùëóformulae-sequenceùõºùë°ùëñsubscriptùëãùë†ùõºùë†ùë†ùë°subscriptùëûùëñùëósubscriptùëãùë°ŒîùëúŒî¬†if¬†ùëñùëó¬†and¬†missing-subexpression‚Ñôconditional-setùõºùë°Œîùëñformulae-sequenceùõºùë°ùëñsubscriptùëãùë†ùõºùë†ùë†ùë°1subscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùëãùë°ŒîùëúŒî\begin{array}[]{ll}&\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\{\alpha(t+\Delta)=j|\alpha(t)=i,X_{s},\alpha(s),s\leq t\}=q_{ij}(X_{t})\Delta+o(\Delta)\text{ if }i\neq j\ \hbox{ and }\\ &\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\{\alpha(t+\Delta)=i|\alpha(t)=i,X_{s},\alpha(s),s\leq t\}=1-q_{i}(X_{t})\Delta+o(\Delta).\end{array} (6.1)

It is proved in [13] that if either Assumption 4.1 or Assumption 2.2 is satisfied with x,y‚àà‚Ñùnùë•ùë¶superscript‚Ñùùëõx,y\in\mathbb{R}^{n} replaced by œï,œà‚ààùíûitalic-œïùúìùíû\phi,\psi\in\mathcal{C}, then there is a unique solution to the switching diffusion (2.1) and (6.1) with a given initial value. Moreover, the process (Xt,Œ±‚Äã(t))subscriptùëãùë°ùõºùë°(X_{t},\alpha(t)) has the Markov-Feller property. With slight modification in the proofs, the theorems in Section 3 still hold for system (2.1) and (6.1).

Our method can also be applied to regime-switching jump diffusion processes. The results obtain by using our method will generalize existing results (e.g., [17, 20]) to the case of regime-switching jump diffusions with countable regimes.

On the other hand, there is a gap between sufficient conditions for stability and instability in Proposition 4.1. To overcome the difficulty, we need to make a polar coordinate transformation to decompose of X‚Äã(t)ùëãùë°X(t) into the radial part r‚Äã(t)=|X‚Äã(t)|ùëüùë°ùëãùë°r(t)=|X(t)| and the angular part Y‚Äã(t)=X‚Äã(t)/r‚Äã(t)ùëåùë°ùëãùë°ùëüùë°Y(t)=X(t)/r(t). Then, the Lyapunov exponents with respect to invariant measures of the linearized process of (Y‚Äã(t),Œ±‚Äã(t))ùëåùë°ùõºùë°(Y(t),\alpha(t)) will determine whether or not the system is stable. This approach has been used to treat many linear and linearized stochastic systems (e.g., [4, 5, 8]). In our setting, the switching Œ±‚Äã(t)ùõºùë°\alpha(t) take values in a noncompact space, thus, it is more difficult to examine invariant measures. We will address this problem together necessary conditions of stability in a subsequent paper.

Lemma A.2.
